theory: The Golden Bell as a Symbol of Eternal Friendship
author: Multiple One Piece fans
description: Many fans theorize that the Golden Bell represents the eternal nature of Noland and Kalgara's friendship. Even though both men died tragically without fulfilling their promise to meet again, the bell continues to ring through the centuries. When Luffy finally rings the bell in episode 195, it serves as the ultimate fulfillment of the promise between Noland and Kalgara, proving that their friendship transcended death and time itself.
evidence: Noland first hears the bell through a storm, guiding him to Jaya
Kalgara promises to ring the bell daily so Noland can always find his way back
The bell becomes silent when Shandora is shot into the sky, breaking the connection
Luffy ringing the bell centuries later fulfills the promise and proves Noland wasn't a liar

theory: Noland and Kalgara's Story as One Piece's Best Flashback
author: TV Tropes Forum Community
description: Fans on TV Tropes and other forums frequently argue that the Noland and Kalgara flashback is one of the best in One Piece history, possibly in the Top 5 or Top 10. Despite the premise being 'side-eye worthy' (a legend about a liar), the execution is so fantastic that it easily makes up for it. The story's tragic ending - two friends who die without fulfilling their promise to each other - is uncommon in One Piece and demonstrates the series' ability to tell emotionally powerful side stories.
evidence: The flashback is consistently rated highly by fans in discussions
The story is frequently cited as an example of One Piece's emotional depth
Many fans report crying during the bell-ringing scene in episode 195
The flashback elevates the entire Skypiea arc in retrospect

theory: The Noland Flashback Redeems the Skypiea Arc
author: One Piece Community
description: Some fans theorize that the Noland and Kalgara flashback is what elevates the Skypiea arc from good to great. While Skypiea is sometimes criticized for feeling disconnected from the main story, the flashback provides emotional weight and thematic depth that makes the entire arc meaningful. The story demonstrates that Skypiea isn't just about defeating Enel - it's about fulfilling a 400-year-old promise and proving the truth about a legendary friendship.
evidence: The flashback gives context and meaning to the entire Skypiea conflict
It connects the past (Noland) to the present (Cricket and Luffy)
The emotional payoff in episode 195 wouldn't work without this setup
It adds layers of cultural conflict and historical tragedy to the arc

theory: Kashigami as a Metaphor for Blind Faith vs. Science
author: Fan Analysis
description: Some fans interpret Kashigami as a metaphorical representation of the conflict between blind faith and scientific reasoning. The Shandia worship the snake as a god and believe only human sacrifice can cure their plague, representing superstition. Noland kills the 'god' and cures the disease with medicine (Conine), representing the triumph of science and reason. However, the story complicates this by showing how Noland's rational actions are seen as culturally insensitive, suggesting neither approach is entirely right or wrong.
evidence: Kashigami is worshipped as a deity despite being just a large snake
The Shandia believe sacrifice will cure Tree Fever (superstition)
Noland uses botanical knowledge and medicine to cure the disease (science)
The cultural conflict shows the complexity of imposing 'rational' beliefs on others

theory: Tree Fever as Historical Commentary on Colonial Disease
author: Fan Community
description: Some fans theorize that Tree Fever serves as commentary on how diseases devastated indigenous populations during the age of exploration. However, Oda subverts the usual narrative - instead of the explorer bringing disease to the natives, Noland brings the cure. This flip suggests a more idealistic vision of cross-cultural contact where knowledge is shared rather than destruction imposed. The story still acknowledges cultural conflict (Noland cutting down the sacred forest) but presents exploration and scientific exchange as potentially beneficial.
evidence: Tree Fever has a 90% fatality rate similar to diseases that devastated real indigenous populations
Noland is an explorer from another sea encountering an indigenous tribe
The conflict arises from cultural misunderstanding rather than malice
Noland brings medical knowledge rather than disease
